params.note: Check each iPSC line for pluripotency by standard differentiation protocol into ecto-, meso-, and endoderm germ layers using traditional markers.
Ensure iPSC lines are free from contaminants.
For genetic disease modeling, obtain patient-derived iPSCs from biobanks or reprogram patient materials; use CRISPR-Cas9 to introduce disease-causing mutations in isogenic iPSCs if needed.
For live imaging, use transgenic iPSC lines with fluorescent reporters under tissue-specific promoters (e.g., retinal progenitors or eye field).
For cell lineage tracing, apply barcoding methods at the iPSC level before differentiation.
Use iPSCs from at least two healthy donors of same gender, cell origin, and age group as control for patient iPSCs.
For CRISPR-Cas9-engineered iPSCs, use the parental cell line as isogenic control.
For ectopic expression of mutant transgene, use original cell line expressing wild-type gene as control.
OVB organoids can be generated from five human iPSC lines; pigmented area formation varies significantly between lines.
Somatic memory effect observed: CRX-iPSCs reprogrammed from Müller ganglion cells showed earlier RPE cell occurrence.
Protocol can be modified to study forebrain development, axis formation, cyclopia, ganglionic eminence, optic stalk, or optic tract by adding media supplements (e.g., BDNF, GDNF, BrainPhys medium).
Set up at least three independent experiments (N = 3 batches); each batch starts from iPSC thawing and proceeds through differentiation.
For each batch, analyze at least three individual organoids (n = 3) per timepoint, treatment, or condition.
For four analysis methods (IF, western blot, ERGs, qRT-PCR), use n = 12 organoids per method (3 per method per batch).
Validation of successful differentiation is only possible after 30 days of culture.
Culturing OVB organoids beyond 60 days leads to degradation and collapse.
Unique expertise required for human iPSC cultivation and differentiation.
Culturing optimization may be needed due to erratic behavior of iPSC donors.
OVB organoids mature to Capowski stage 2–3; lack mature retinal cell types and retina-cortex connectivity.
Quality check: pigmented areas visible by eye or magnifier.
Generation of ~40 OVB organoids per batch is realistic; manual processing limits scalability.
Due to dominant brain tissue, retinal/non-neuronal cell types are limited in bulk or scRNA-seq, requiring many organoids and reducing cost-effectiveness.
